datafield.subfield: Reconstructing gravity beyond the local universe with peculiar velocities
Reconstructing gravity beyond the local universe with peculiar velocities
Reconstructing the velocity field beyond the local universe
Accepted for publication in General Relativity and Gravitation (GRG)

We present a maximum probability approach to reconstructing spatial maps of the peculiar velocity field at redshifts $z\sim0.1$, where the velocities have been measured from distance indicators (DI) such as $D_n-\sigma$ relations or Tully-Fisher. With the large statistical uncertainties associated with DIs, our reconstruction method aims to recover the underlying true peculiar velocity field by reducing these errors with the use of two physically motivated filtering prior terms. The first constructs an estimate of the velocity field derived from the galaxy over-density {\deltag} and the second makes use of the matter linear density power spectrum {\pk}. Using $N$-body simulations we find, with an SDSS-like sample ($N_{gal}\simeq33$ per deg$^2$), an average correlation coefficient value of $r=0.55\pm{0.02}$ between our reconstructed velocity field and that of the true velocity field from the simulation. However, with a suitably high number density of galaxies from the next generation surveys (e.g. $N_{gal}\simeq140$ per deg$^2$) we can achieve an average $r=0.70\pm{0.02}$ out to moderate redshifts $z\sim0.1$. This will prove useful for future tests of gravity, as these relatively deep maps are complementary to weak lensing maps at the same redshift.

00000 \small Left to right: distributions of true distances (black) and our simulated inferred distances (red) with lognormal errors added with a $\sigma_d=0.3$. The initial simulated cube is $0 < z_C/$~$h^{-1}$Mpc $< 384$ on the side and we have shifted its position to $384<z_C/h^{-1}$Mpc$~<~768$ (middle panel) and $768~<~z_C/$~$h^{-1}$~Mpc$~<~1151$ (right panel) to explore the effect of these errors at larger distances. $z_C$ denotes the $z$-component of the vector position $\mathbf{r}$.

00012 \small Correlation coefficient values for the final reconstruction of the peculiar velocity field. The bottom panels show the correlation between r[{\vnoise},{\vtrue}] (red points) for each redshift slice in our simulated galaxy cubes: $0.09<z\le 0.18$ on the left panel and $0.18<z\le 0.27$ on the right panel. The black points show the mean correlation value for the 1000 MC samples and the true velocity field i.e. r[ {\vrec},{\vtrue}]. The top panels show the respective residual correlations between the {\vtrue} (black points) and {\vrec} (blue points), where $\epsilon$ is the residual, $\epsilon$~=~{\vtrue}~-~{\vrec}.

00013 \small The error power spectrum compared for the various velocity fields. The red line shows the power spectrum of the true velocity field {\vtrue}, the blue line is the power spectrum on the {\dphi} field (computed from the galaxy over density) and the green line is the power spectrum of the observed noisy input velocity map {\vnoise}. The dashed black line shows the residual power of ({\dphi} - {\vrec}), where {\vrec} is the reconstructed velocity field for the first $n=1$ iteration of the algorithm. The solid black line is then the residual power for the final iteration of the algorithm at $n=20,000$.

00014 \small The effect of the different prior terms on the reconstruction. The left panel shows the final reconstruction of the velocity field where no prior terms have been activated. The second panel shows the final reconstruction when only the $P_k$ power spectrum prior term is applied with a {\sigmapkv}=0.1{\pktrue}. The third shows the reconstruction with the baryon $\delta_v$ prior term only with a {\sigmadphi}=1000.0 {\kms}. Finally, the fourth shows the combination of the two prior terms.

00015 \small Artificially embedding a large structure into the {\psitrue} field and allowing it to propagate into the $\delta_v$ prior term. In both sets of panels, the top row shows the {\psitrue} field as computed from the galaxy over-density $\delta_g$. The second row is the resulting gradient of that potential along the z-direction as denoted by {\dphi}. The third row is the distribution between {\dphi} and {\vtrue}. The fourth row is the final reconstructed velocity field, {\vrec}, for that particular slice in redshift. Finally, the bottom row is the distribution of {\vrec} and {\vtrue}. The red lines on the scatter plots indicate the least squares fit. For the left panel set at $0.135 < z \le 0.141$, the left-hand columns are the results where no artificial mass has been added to the simulations. In the right-hand column a gaussian mass has been added across 4 slices in $z$ to the $\Psi$ field, centred at $X$ and $Y$ pixel coordinates [11,12]. The effect of this on the {\dphi} field is then shown. In the right-hand panel set we can see this mass continuing in the subsequent redshift slice at $0.141 < z \le 0.146$. In both cases we can observe how this mass affects the resulting {\dphi} field in the distributions of [{\dphi},{\vtrue}] in the second row.

00016 \small Artificially embedding a large structure into the {\psitrue} field and allowing it to propagate into the $\delta_v$ prior term. In both sets of panels, the top row shows the {\psitrue} field as computed from the galaxy over-density $\delta_g$. The second row is the resulting gradient of that potential along the z-direction as denoted by {\dphi}. The third row is the distribution between {\dphi} and {\vtrue}. The fourth row is the final reconstructed velocity field, {\vrec}, for that particular slice in redshift. Finally, the bottom row is the distribution of {\vrec} and {\vtrue}. The red lines on the scatter plots indicate the least squares fit. For the left panel set at $0.135 < z \le 0.141$, the left-hand columns are the results where no artificial mass has been added to the simulations. In the right-hand column a gaussian mass has been added across 4 slices in $z$ to the $\Psi$ field, centred at $X$ and $Y$ pixel coordinates [11,12]. The effect of this on the {\dphi} field is then shown. In the right-hand panel set we can see this mass continuing in the subsequent redshift slice at $0.141 < z \le 0.146$. In both cases we can observe how this mass affects the resulting {\dphi} field in the distributions of [{\dphi},{\vtrue}] in the second row.
00017 \small Similar test to that shown in Figure~\ref{fig:masstest1}, where now we embed an under-density in the maps.
00018 \small Similar test to that shown in Figure~\ref{fig:masstest1}, where now we embed an under-density in the maps.

00019 \small Example of the final reconstruction of the $\Psi$ field for the $0.08<z\le 0.18$ simulated galaxy cube. In this example we show the $0.107 < z< 0.113$ reconstructed slice. The top row panels show the true $\Psi$ field {\psitrue}. The second row shows the final reconstructed $\Psi$ field {\psirec} map and the third row is the residual map $\epsilon$ between {\psitrue} and {\psirec}. Finally, the bottom-left panel is the distribution of [{\psirec},{\psitrue}], and the bottom-right panel is the observed velocity distribution {\vnoise} compared to the true velocity distribution {\vtrue}. In both of these panels we show the correlation $r$ between the variables and the fitted slope $a$ (also indicated by the red line).

00020 \small The correlation coefficient values $r$ for the final reconstruction of the $\Psi$ field for the $0.08<z\le 0.18$ simulated galaxy cube. The top panels show the correlations between the residual maps $\epsilon$ and {\psitrue} (shown in red) and {\psirec} (shown in blue). The bottom panel shows the correlation coefficient values between {\psitrue} and the reconstruction {\psirec} within each of the 16 slices in redshift of the reconstructed cube.

00021 \small Resulting velocity reconstruction for SDSS type survey. In both panel sets we have reduced the number of galaxies in our simulated cubes from 300,000 to 70,000 to reflect a SDSS type survey. In the left-hand panel set we have selected the $0.169 <z<0174$ slice from the first simulated cube which ranges $0.008<z<z0.18$. The top row is the true velocity field {\vtrue}, the second tow is the final reconstructed velocity field {\vrec} and the third row is the residual map $\epsilon$ between {\vtrue} and {\vrec}. The bottom-left panel shows the [{\vtrue},{\vrec}] distribution and the bottom-right panel is the [{\vtrue},{\vnoise}] distribution. In both cases the correlation coefficient $r$ is shown as well as the slope $a$ also shown as the red line. The right-hand panel set shows the $0.217<z<0.222$ reconstruction from the second simulated cube which ranges $0.18<z<z0.27$.

00022 \small Resulting velocity reconstruction for SDSS type survey. In both panel sets we have reduced the number of galaxies in our simulated cubes from 300,000 to 70,000 to reflect a SDSS type survey. In the left-hand panel set we have selected the $0.169 <z<0174$ slice from the first simulated cube which ranges $0.008<z<z0.18$. The top row is the true velocity field {\vtrue}, the second tow is the final reconstructed velocity field {\vrec} and the third row is the residual map $\epsilon$ between {\vtrue} and {\vrec}. The bottom-left panel shows the [{\vtrue},{\vrec}] distribution and the bottom-right panel is the [{\vtrue},{\vnoise}] distribution. In both cases the correlation coefficient $r$ is shown as well as the slope $a$ also shown as the red line. The right-hand panel set shows the $0.217<z<0.222$ reconstruction from the second simulated cube which ranges $0.18<z<z0.27$.

00023 \small Correlation coefficient values for the final reconstruction of the peculiar velocity field for a SDSS type survey sample. The bottom panels show the correlation between r[{\vnoise},{\vtrue}] (red points) for each redshift slice in our simulated galaxy cubes; $0.09<z\le 0.18$ (left panels) and $0.18<z\le 0.270$ (right panels). The black points show the correlation of the true velocity field i.e. r[{\vrecf},{\vtrue}] and the grey points show r[{\vrecf},{\vtrue}] from Figure~\ref{fig:vrec_rho_bs}. The top panels show the respective residual correlations between the {\vtrue} (black points) and {\vrecf} (blue points), where $\epsilon$ is the residual, $\epsilon$~=~{\vtrue}~-~{\vrecf}.

00001 \small Example of the spatial true velocity map compared to our simulated observed velocity field. The top row shows {\vtrue} maps at two different redshift slices: $0.0 <$ \zcos $< 0.006$ (left) and $0.084 <$ \zcos $< 0.09$ (right). The bottom panels show the corresponding observed noisy velocity maps {\vnoise} where lognormal random noise of {\sigsq} = 0.3 has been propagated from the distances. Here \zcos\, denotes $H_0 z_C/c$.

00002 \small The correlation $r$ between the true velocity field {\vtrue} and observed velocity field {\vnoise} for {\sigsq} = 0.3 at increasing redshift slices. The fitted slope is shown as a red line and given by the quantity $a$.
00003 \small Correction applied to the velocity $\chi^2$ term, to remove offset of observed distances from true distances.

00004 \small Distribution of the velocity field {\vtrue} and the {\dphi} field derived for selected redshift slices. The quantity $r$ is the correlation coefficient. The quantity $a$ is the slope from a least-squares fit with the best-fit shown as a solid red line. The one-to-one relationship is shown as a dotted grey line.

00005 \small Comparing the {\dphi} and {\vtrue} velocity spatial maps of the redshift slice $0 < z < 0.006$ from Figure~\ref{fig:dphiscatter}. First panel shows the total number of galaxies within each pixel for that slice. Second panel: from this we compute the {\psitrue} field from Equation~\ref{equ:phi}. The third panel shows the resulting gradient of the {\psitrue} field, which we can then compare to the true velocity field {\vtrue} shown in the fourth panel, computed from the z-component velocities of the simulation.
00006 \small Flow chart summarising the velocity reconstruction algorithm. See main text for details.

00007 \small Final reconstruction of the $0.09<z\le 0.18$ (upper panel sets) and $0.18<z\le 0.27$ (lower panel sets) simulated galaxy cubes. For the left-hand panel sets, the top row shows the true velocity field and the middle row is the final reconstruction from the mean of 1000 MCs. The bottom row left panel is the distribution of [{\vtrue},{\vrec}], and the bottom row right panel is the observed velocity distribution {\vnoise} compared to the true velocity distribution {\vtrue}. In both of these panels we show the correlation $r$ between the variables and the fitted slope $a$ (also indicated by the red line). The right hand panel sets show the residual map (top row) $\epsilon=${\vtrue}-{\vrec}, the MC error map (middle row) and the covariance of the reconstructed velocity map (bottom row).

00008 \small Final reconstruction of the $0.09<z\le 0.18$ (upper panel sets) and $0.18<z\le 0.27$ (lower panel sets) simulated galaxy cubes. For the left-hand panel sets, the top row shows the true velocity field and the middle row is the final reconstruction from the mean of 1000 MCs. The bottom row left panel is the distribution of [{\vtrue},{\vrec}], and the bottom row right panel is the observed velocity distribution {\vnoise} compared to the true velocity distribution {\vtrue}. In both of these panels we show the correlation $r$ between the variables and the fitted slope $a$ (also indicated by the red line). The right hand panel sets show the residual map (top row) $\epsilon=${\vtrue}-{\vrec}, the MC error map (middle row) and the covariance of the reconstructed velocity map (bottom row).

00009 \small Final reconstruction of the $0.09<z\le 0.18$ (upper panel sets) and $0.18<z\le 0.27$ (lower panel sets) simulated galaxy cubes. For the left-hand panel sets, the top row shows the true velocity field and the middle row is the final reconstruction from the mean of 1000 MCs. The bottom row left panel is the distribution of [{\vtrue},{\vrec}], and the bottom row right panel is the observed velocity distribution {\vnoise} compared to the true velocity distribution {\vtrue}. In both of these panels we show the correlation $r$ between the variables and the fitted slope $a$ (also indicated by the red line). The right hand panel sets show the residual map (top row) $\epsilon=${\vtrue}-{\vrec}, the MC error map (middle row) and the covariance of the reconstructed velocity map (bottom row).

00010 \small Final reconstruction of the $0.09<z\le 0.18$ (upper panel sets) and $0.18<z\le 0.27$ (lower panel sets) simulated galaxy cubes. For the left-hand panel sets, the top row shows the true velocity field and the middle row is the final reconstruction from the mean of 1000 MCs. The bottom row left panel is the distribution of [{\vtrue},{\vrec}], and the bottom row right panel is the observed velocity distribution {\vnoise} compared to the true velocity distribution {\vtrue}. In both of these panels we show the correlation $r$ between the variables and the fitted slope $a$ (also indicated by the red line). The right hand panel sets show the residual map (top row) $\epsilon=${\vtrue}-{\vrec}, the MC error map (middle row) and the covariance of the reconstructed velocity map (bottom row).

00011 \small {\it Left panel:} An example of the distribution of the correlation coefficient $r$ for the 1000 MC velocity reconstructions ({\vbs}) and the true velocity field ({\vtrue}) at a redshift slice $0.264 < z \le 270$. {\it Right panel:} Velocity distribution for 1000 MC reconstructions in a single pixel. In both panels the results were derived from the second simulated cube which was shifted to the redshift range $0.18 < z \le 0.27$ with a {\sigsq}=0.3 error added to the observed distances.
